body:
This is going to be a good thing, but do not forget to add the following lists:
- https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/librustc_resolve/diagnostics.rs
- https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/librustc_typeck/diagnostics.rs
- https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/librustc_borrowck/diagnostics.rs
Thanks! I wasn't aware of those!

I'll take E0152 through E0170, thanks!

Question: Should I squash all the additions into a single commit, or keep them separate?
I'll take E0009 (a little start to begin).

@lfairy: Either is fine. If there are logical slabs of messages that could also work well.

@GuillaumeGomez: Sounds good :smile:
Thanks!

I’ll take E0297 through E0302 (the ones in check_match). Edit: I’ll take E0162 and E0165 as well. I have not been able to come up with an example that causes 298, 299 or 300. Does anybody have a snippet that causes these? Anything I try fails with a type mismatch. Similarly, I have not been able to produce 158 yet, but there is an unnumbered error with a similar message. (Maybe those should be reconciled?)
@ruud-v-a I'm already working on 158/162/165 (see my comment above)

Sorry Chris, I only just noticed this now... If you have anything to add to Ruud's descriptions go ahead!

I was hoping I could transform the list into a more complete one, but my script is somewhat broken so I'm looking into better ways to extract error information (uniqueness checking, finding errors without descriptions, HTML output). For now I've marked who's working on what in the current list.
I just did E0296.
I'll also take the loop ones, E0267 and E0268.

@michaelsproul No worries :)

I'll take E0306 and E0307.
Could I try E0308-E0311?
@cactorium: Go for it! :smile:
@lfairy: oops, my apologies. I hope you don’t mind.
I've tried my hand at E0015 and E0020
I now take E0018 (should I open a new PR for it or not ?).
@GuillaumeGomez: You'll need a new PR as your previous one was just approved
@michaelsproul: Yes, I just saw that.
I took a stab at E0133.
I'll now take E0271.
I'm looking at E0013.
@robinst :smile:
@michaelsproul: could you take a look at #24728 please ? I'm kinda stuck to see what to add and/or improve (and @pnkfelix doesn't know what would be missing).

I encountered a very misleading instance of E0282 just yet. I’m writing the long documentation for it as we speak and I improved the error message.

By the way, if any one wants to have a go at 298, 299 or 300, feel free to do so, I have not been able to reproduce them yet.

Ok, don't be scared but I've just added error codes from the rest of the compiler...

![](http://i.imgur.com/1eOYJxy.png)

Who's up for round two?

@steveklabnik could you tag this issue as E-Easy to help new people find it? Thanks :smile:
Well, as soon as my current one is finished, I'm totally up to ! :-)

:scream:

I've taken a shot at E0046 and E0054

And now also E0062, E0063 and E0137.

I intended to try E0136, but so far I've been unable to reproduce it. This error message is `multiple 'main' functions`, but when trying to reproduce it with:

``` rust
fn main() {}
fn main() {}
```

the error you get is not E0136, but

```
E0136.rs:2:1: 2:13 error: duplicate definition of value `main`
E0136.rs:2 fn main() {}
           ^~~~~~~~~~~~
E0136.rs:1:1: 1:13 note: first definition of value `main` here
E0136.rs:1 fn main() {}
           ^~~~~~~~~~~~
error: aborting due to previous error
```
@nham: Have you tried in another file ?
Oh, wait, that's E0137.
It seems like E0136 may never be hit. Hm.

Taking E0067. I'll do a few others too if I can.

Making a list as I take these:
- E0067
- E0131
- E0132

As an aside, what qualifies an error to receive an ID/explanation?
@caipre: Ideally all errors that are printed by the compiler should be assigned an error code. Nobody has sat down and done it yet though.
I just did E0317.
Awesome work everyone! :smile:
Meanwhile, I also did E0154, E0259 and E0260.
I've also added E0249 and E0250 in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/25272
I'll take E0011 to E0019.

I'm now working on:
- E0106, E0107 (as previously mentioned)
- E0049, E0050
- E0066
- E0069
- E0166
- E0201
- E0322

Should we use a shared spreadsheet to keep track of things? I had a go at making one:

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Qt8Bs6qp4NLP2FYQ361CZ4U-3OsUWNCLQX3c_jGtvqM/edit?usp=sharing
@michaelsproul Good idea. I'll keep the spreadsheet updated for the errors I do.
@nham: Great! I'll remove the clunky check list.
Cheers @Manishearth :smile:

(Just comment `@Manishearth r+ please` or something on them -- I've been largely ignoring these PRs since I knew you were coordinating them and didn't want to cause merge conflicts by reviewing the wrong ones -- but I shouldn't have to do that ^_^)
I can't figure out how to trigger E0311, but I'm up for trying a couple more! Could I grab E0197-E0200?
Sure; just add your name next to them in the spreadsheet above!

It looks like E0134/E0135 ("modification of string types is not allowed") may not be triggerable. These were added in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/9750, back when it was possible to index individual bytes of strings, and I don't think it's possible to do that today. The error you get instead is

```
 the trait `core::ops::Index<_>` is not implemented for the type `collections::string::String` [E0277]
```
I'm currently working on E0038, and may have a look at the other trait stuff.

@michaelsproul a policy question: Should error explanations include references to unstable features, that is, features that are hidden behind a feature-gate, and thus are unavailable in stable and beta channels of Rust?

A concrete example of this is #26396, which is explaining E0019 (that you cannot call functions from the initializer for a const definition).  It might be good to mention `const fn` in that explanation, since they were essentially added precisely to allow such code to be written.

My first thought was that we should not include such discussion, since it would confuse people on the stable/beta channels.

But my second thought was that it is better for us to make the error explanation documentation as complete as possible, at the moment when people are working on it.  It will be harder to try to go back over previous error explanations and update them as features land.

A third thought is that we could maybe extend the error explanation infrastructure to allow for an additional documentation string that is separated from the others and is _only_ printed from a Rust that is on the nightly channel.  That way, people on stable/beta won't see such messages, while the people on nightly get the benefit of seeing how new features may help them resolve their problems.

@pnkfelix: Adding an additionnal string would be nice, but it'd be even nicer if in stable/beta it's printed with a warning (or something similar) in order to say "it's not possible for now but hold on! Feature is coming!".
@michaelsproul: The google doc wasn't up to date so I updated it. I think it's good now.

Great!

I also realised I never commented regarding unstable features. I think Felix's reasoning is solid. I'll have a play-around with a system for printing different strings on different versions.
I'm not sure how to trigger E0079, E0308 keeps getting in the way. Anyone want to try?
It looks like the spreadsheet says michaelsproul already finished that one

I'm working on improving existing ones

-----Original Message-----
From: "cactorium" notifications@github.com
Sent: ‎7/‎11/‎2015 9:12 PM
To: "rust-lang/rust" rust@noreply.github.com
Cc: "Manish Goregaokar" manishsmail@gmail.com
Subject: Re: [rust] Add error explanations for all error codes (trackingissue). (#24407)

It looks like the spreadsheet says michaelsproul already finished that one
—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
playpen: http://is.gd/cAbc2m
Note: I'm taking a global lock on librustc/ for a while, trying to clear up all of them in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/26963. I'll comment here when I'm done :)

Are the explanations intended to be read at a terminal or as a webpage?

I ask, because, in the former context, some of the pseudo-Markdown constructs are harder to follow.  For example, `for _all_ possible types` clearly emphasises one word; however, `containing _every object that implements the trait_` is harder to follow given it spans multiple words (and, in the context I've lifted this from, across multiple lines). IMHO, this would be fine were there emphasis in the console context; it reads fine in the web context as emphasis can be displayed.

(It occurs to me that a way out of this is to add console escape sequences to allow bold or underlined emphasis in `rustc --explain` output...)

@jashank Both.

We may add rudimentary bolding and code formatting to the console version later.
(I probably should remove the long-emphasis on that sentence though)
OK, that seems reasonable; there are a few instances of long-emphasis that could probably be removed.
I'm taking a look at 382 now.
Just a note here in addition to the spreadsheet - 225 and 223 appear to be assigned to @nham and are marked as merged, but I don't see them in the latest code.
Then remove him from the assignee in the spreadsheet please (or maybe @nham is still working on it?). I don't see any PR either.
Yeah, I wasn't sure if it was accidentally marked as merged, or accidentally marked as assigned too :-)
Maybe both ! :p
_grins_ indeed!  Perhaps I'll remove it for now, but @nham can let us know if that's wrong.
Hrmm, I do not recall trying to do anything with those error codes. It's fine for anyone else to take them.
Fab - I'll take a look at 225 then.
I'm also taking 223.
@AlisdairO: You're on fire ! :D
@GuillaumeGomez thanks :D.  I have a couple of days before my first child is due to arrive, so I'm squeezing in as much as I can now, as I figure I won't have much time for a while after :-).
Congrats ! \o/

Thanks @GuillaumeGomez :-)

OK, I'm going to take a look at E0281 and E0373 next
Er, wait, 281 is in librustc.  @Manishearth am I OK to take a look at that, or do you want it?  I have a simple reproduction if that would help.

Take it :smile: 

if you want to do something in librustc just check my mega PR first and leave a comment.
Fab, cheers!
Releasing lock on `librustc/`
Gonna grab E0074-E0077
I updated the [spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Qt8Bs6qp4NLP2FYQ361CZ4U-3OsUWNCLQX3c_jGtvqM/edit#gid=0). Only a few are now remaining, good job everyone ! \o/
I'll try E0384.
I'll take 387.
I'll have a go at E0193.
Taking E0194 and E0404 also.
The E0404 has already be done (I didn't add these errors in the spreadsheet, you have to research for them before adding them, sorry about that ^^').
Ah yes, thanks for letting me know :)
I'll also have a go at 122, 221 and 214.

I'll also take a look at E0248.

With this one I think we now have 3/4 of the diagnostics either assigned or merged :-)
@AlisdairO: A bit more. Thanks for your help !
@GuillaumeGomez it's been fun!
@AlisdairO: I hope so ! :D
It's probably much more than that -- I think I still need to update the spreadsheet for my librustc PR

Nevermind, someone seems to have helpfully updated the spreadsheet for me (or I did it and forgot :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes: )

I think some codes aren't noted in the spreadsheet at all, though. No biggie since the number of remaining codes is shrinking, we don't need to keep track of all of them now
@Manishearth: I did. :p
I'll give E0329, E0366, and E0367 a go too.
I'm happy to take on `E0383` as a first stab at a contribution! :smiley:
Great! Let us know if you need any help!
Raised a PR for `E0383` at #27699, will now take `E0386`.

I forgot to said (I just updated the spreadsheet, btw, don't forget to update it people !) but I'm on all these: E0103, E0323, E0324, E0325, E0369 and E0425. [Maybe more will come](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/27586) !
Also taking 321
I'm not convinced that E0247 is possible.  Any attempt to use a module in place of a type gets captured by E0412 use of undeclared type name `{}`
@AlisdairO: I'll give a try to E0390 then.
Commit hash faf73028c9afe5790e9b4d83a348d93e4a098852 removed E0266, so removing from spreadsheet.
Its still good to have an explanation for 247, in case things get moved around in the future. Mention in a comment that the error is currently unreachable.
OK, I'll take E0247 then.
@AlisdairO: Hi ! Are you still working on E0321 and E0329 ? I'd like to give them a shot if you're not. :)
hey - still on them at the moment if that's alright!
No worries, since it's been 11 days, I was just asking. Take good care of your little you ! :)
thanks :)

I'd like to see some description added to a specific error message: 

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/librustc_borrowck/borrowck/gather_loans/move_error.rs#L123

I notice that this is not in the spreadsheet/no EXXXX designation is associated with it. Is there any specific reason there is no error code associated with it?

@joelmccracken No reason, we should fix that. @GuillaumeGomez has been working on these

That's basically the "next step" of this issue.
- Step 1: Explain existing error codes
- Step 2: Add more error codes and explain them
- Step 3: Add inline notes to errors whenever there are one or two very common, non-obvious solutions or causes
I will take a more global look when I have time. Thanks for reporting this @joelmccracken.
